definitions.definition: The trail of scent left by someone wearing perfume.

examples: Her distinctive perfume left a sillage that lingered in the room long after she had departed.
Luxury fragrances often boast of their impressive sillage and longevity.
He could track her movement through the party by following her sillage.

definitions.definition: A design feature copied from a similar feature in another object, even when not functionally necessary.

examples: The digital notepad app uses a skeuomorph of lined paper and margins to evoke a familiar experience.
Early automobiles featured skeuomorphs of horse-drawn carriages in their design.
The designer argued against using skeuomorphs, preferring interfaces that embraced digital affordances.

definitions.definition: Small fragments; tiny pieces.

examples: The vase fell and shattered into smithereens on the tile floor.
The explosion reduced the building to smithereens.
His carefully constructed argument was blown to smithereens by the opposing evidence.

definitions.definition: A nickname, especially one given to a person that is descriptive in a humorous way.

examples: William 'Refrigerator' Perry earned his sobriquet due to his immense size and strength.
The sobriquet 'The Iron Lady' perfectly captured Margaret Thatcher's resolute leadership style.
Throughout history, kings and queens have often been known by sobriquets that reflected their character or achievements.

definitions.definition: To utter a soliloquy; to talk to oneself.

examples: The elderly professor would often soliloquize while walking through the campus gardens.
Hamlet's famous 'To be or not to be' occurs when he soliloquizes about existence and suicide.
Modern films rarely allow characters to soliloquize, preferring voiceover narration for inner thoughts.

definitions.definition: The act or habit of talking in one's sleep.

examples: His roommate was disturbed by his frequent somniloquy, which sometimes included shouting.
Researchers recorded episodes of somniloquy to study subconscious language patterns.
Her somniloquy revealed a fluency in Spanish that she struggled to access while awake.

definitions.definition: The profound realization that each random passerby is living a life as vivid and complex as your own.

examples: Sitting in the busy cafe, she was overcome with sonder as she watched the countless lives intersecting around her.
The documentary aimed to inspire sonder by portraying the rich inner lives of seemingly ordinary people.
Travelers often report experiencing intense sonder when observing daily life in foreign cities.

definitions.definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
A drug or substance that induces sleep.

examples: The professor's monotonous voice had a soporific effect on the entire class.
The herbal tea contained several natural soporifics to aid with insomnia.
The soporific quality of the heavy meal made it difficult to return to work afterward.

definitions.definition: An intuitive sense of what is linguistically appropriate; an ear for idioms and syntax.

examples: Native speakers develop sprachgefühl naturally, knowing when something sounds right without necessarily being able to explain the grammatical rules.
The translator's excellent sprachgefühl allowed her to create natural-sounding dialogue in the target language.
Learning idiomatic expressions can help language students develop their sprachgefühl.

definitions.definition: A soft murmuring or rustling sound; a whisper.

examples: The susurration of leaves in the breeze was the only sound in the forest.
There was a constant susurration of gossip following the unexpected announcement.
The gentle susurration of the stream helped her fall asleep despite her worries.

definitions.definition: A whispering or rustling sound.

examples: The susurrus of leaves in the breeze was the only sound in the forest.
She could hear the susurrus of hushed conversations as she entered the room.
The poem attempted to capture in words the gentle susurrus of waves on a pebble beach.

definitions.definition: An alignment of three celestial bodies (such as the sun, moon, and earth) in a straight line.
A pair of connected or corresponding things.

examples: A solar eclipse occurs during a syzygy of the sun, moon, and Earth.
The poet explored the syzygy between human emotion and natural phenomena.
Astronomers carefully track the timing of planetary syzygies to plan observations.

definitions.definition: A small lie; a fib.
Pretentious nonsense.

examples: The child told a charming taradiddle about fairies stealing the missing cookies.
Political speeches are often full of taradiddle designed to appeal to voters without making concrete promises.
Her explanation was dismissed as mere taradiddle by those who knew the truth.

definitions.definition: A petty lie or fabrication.

examples: The child told a charming tarradiddle about why the cookies had disappeared.
The memoir was filled with tarradiddles that exaggerated the author's adventures.
She considered the white lie a harmless tarradiddle to spare her friend's feelings.

definitions.definition: A lover of the sea or ocean; someone who finds peace or joy near the ocean.

examples: As a dedicated thalassophile, she couldn't imagine living anywhere without an ocean view.
The thalassophile spent every weekend exploring different coastal areas and beaches.
His photography captured the unique perspective of a thalassophile, focusing on the meeting of land and sea.

definitions.definition: The ringing or sound of bells.

examples: The tintinnabulation of the church bells echoed through the valley every Sunday morning.
Edgar Allan Poe's poem 'The Bells' uses the word 'tintinnabulation' to evoke the lingering sound of bells.
The gentle tintinnabulation of wind chimes filled the garden.

definitions.definition: The separation of parts of a compound word by an intervening word or words, used for emphasis or humorous effect.

examples: The phrase 'un-freaking-believable' is an example of tmesis in modern slang.
Shakespeare used tmesis in 'Othello' with the line 'This is the monst-terrible oath that I can give.'
Australian English frequently employs tmesis in expressions like 'abso-bloody-lutely'.

definitions.definition: Mentally or physically inactive; lethargic.
(Of an animal) dormant from a lowered body temperature and metabolic rate.

examples: The extreme heat left everyone torpid and unable to concentrate.
Many reptiles become torpid during cold weather.
The economy remained torpid despite attempts to stimulate growth.

definitions.definition: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
Sharp; cutting.

examples: Her trenchant analysis of the policy revealed its fundamental flaws.
The book review was so trenchant that the author publicly responded to defend his work.
His trenchant wit made him a popular but feared dinner guest.

definitions.definition: A collector of cheese labels.

examples: The dedicated tyrosemiophile's album contained rare labels from small artisanal creameries around the world.
At the tyrosemiophile convention, collectors traded duplicate labels to complete their collections.
Her interest in cheese evolved from gourmet appreciation to becoming a serious tyrosemiophile with over 500 labels.

definitions.definition: Having woolly or crispy hair.

examples: The anthropology paper discussed the distribution of ulotrichous populations around the world.
His ulotrichous hair formed tight coils that he wore in a natural style.
The ulotrichous texture of the sheep's coat made it particularly valuable for certain types of wool production.

definitions.definition: Expressing opinions on matters outside the scope of one's knowledge or expertise.
A person who expresses opinions on matters outside the scope of their knowledge or expertise.

examples: The talk show host's ultracrepidarian comments on complex scientific issues frequently frustrated actual experts.
She was tired of ultracrepidarians on social media confidently dispensing medical advice without any qualifications.
His ultracrepidarian tendencies diminished his credibility even when speaking about topics he genuinely understood.

definitions.definition: A category of taste in food corresponding to the flavor of glutamates, especially monosodium glutamate; a savory taste.

examples: The addition of dried mushrooms intensified the umami flavor of the broth.
Aged cheeses and fermented foods are rich in umami compounds.
The chef described umami as the fifth taste, complementing sweet, sour, salty, and bitter.

definitions.definition: Casting or making shade.

examples: They sought relief from the summer heat under the umbriferous oak trees.
The architect designed umbriferous courtyards to create cool spaces in the hot climate.
The umbriferous forest canopy prevented much sunlight from reaching the forest floor.

definitions.definition: A wish or inclination not strong enough to lead to action.

examples: His velleity to learn Japanese never progressed beyond purchasing a textbook that remained unopened.
New Year's resolutions often remain mere velleities, abandoned by February.
She had a persistent velleity to visit Antarctica, but never seriously researched or planned such a trip.

definitions.definition: The strange wistfulness of used bookstores, which are somehow infused with the passage of time.

examples: The vellichor of the antiquarian bookshop transported her to another era.
He spent hours browsing, enveloped in the vellichor of stacked shelves and forgotten tomes.
There's a certain vellichor that can't be replicated in modern retail spaces.

definitions.definition: The appearance of being true or real.

examples: The historical drama was praised for its verisimilitude in depicting 18th-century London.
Good science fiction maintains verisimilitude by creating consistent rules for its imagined world.
The courtroom scene lacked verisimilitude, containing procedures that would never happen in an actual trial.

definitions.definition: A diagonal stroke (/) used especially to separate alternatives, as in 'and/or'.

examples: The poet used the virgule to indicate line breaks when quoting verse within prose.
Legal documents often employ the virgule in constructions like 'he/she' to ensure gender neutrality.
The editor replaced all instances of 'and-or' with 'and/or', employing the virgule for clarity.

definitions.definition: Exhausted, worn out, or tired; slightly unwell.

examples: After hiking for eight hours, she was completely wabbit and fell asleep immediately.
He looked a bit wabbit this morning; perhaps he's coming down with something.
The children were wabbit after their day at the amusement park.

definitions.definition: Overcome with indigestion; sick with nausea.

examples: After the rich holiday meal, he felt thoroughly wamblecropt and declined dessert.
The rough sea journey left most passengers wamblecropt and seeking their cabins.
The smell of the chemistry experiment left her feeling wamblecropt for hours afterward.

definitions.definition: A feeling of melancholy and world-weariness.

examples: The poetry of the Romantic era often expressed a profound weltschmerz.
Reading the news headlines induced a temporary weltschmerz that colored her whole day.
His weltschmerz deepened as he realized how far reality fell short of his ideals.

definitions.definition: A toy that spins or whirls, such as a top or pinwheel.
A carousel or merry-go-round.
A constant round of activity; a whirl.

examples: Children gathered around the street performer who operated a traditional wooden whiligig.
The week before the wedding was a whiligig of preparations and social events.
The county fair featured an antique whiligig that had been carefully restored.

definitions.definition: In a direction contrary to the sun's course, counterclockwise.
In a direction opposite to the usual; contrary, reverse.

examples: Ancient superstitions warned against walking widdershins around a church.
The ritual required participants to move widdershins around the stone circle three times.
Her life seemed to be moving widdershins to everyone else's—sleeping during the day and working through the night.

definitions.definition: A neurological condition characterized by a tendency to make inappropriate jokes and puns, and to tell pointless or irrelevant stories, usually resulting from damage to the brain.

examples: Following his frontal lobe injury, he developed witzelsucht, compulsively making puns that only he found amusing.
The neurologist diagnosed witzelsucht when the patient couldn't stop making jokes during the serious medical consultation.
Researchers study witzelsucht to better understand the brain's role in humor processing and social inhibition.

definitions.definition: A person who fears or dislikes foreigners or people from different cultures.

examples: The xenophobe refused to try any cuisine from outside his own country.
Historical xenophobes have often opposed immigration and cultural exchange.
She worried that travel restrictions were turning her country into a nation of xenophobes.

definitions.definition: To gulp down quickly and greedily.

examples: After the long hike, he xertzed an entire bottle of water without pausing for breath.
The children xertzed their milkshakes, resulting in predictable brain freeze.
In competitive eating contests, participants must xertz astonishing quantities of food in minutes.

definitions.definition: A hand of cards containing no card above a nine; a worthless hand.

examples: He looked disappointed as he folded his yarborough without placing a bet.
The probability of being dealt a yarborough in bridge is approximately 1 in 1828.
She'd had nothing but yarboroughs all evening, making it her worst game in months.

definitions.definition: To hiccup or sob.

examples: The baby yexed after feeding too quickly.
He continued to yex for several minutes after the laughing fit subsided.
In old literature, characters often yex with grief during emotional scenes.

definitions.definition: (Of a woman) having a full, rounded figure; pleasingly plump.

examples: The painter was known for his portraits of zaftig women, a contrast to the fashion industry's ideals.
Historical beauty standards often preferred zaftig figures, as evidenced in Renaissance art.
The actress embraced her zaftig physique rather than pursuing the industry's typical slender aesthetic.

definitions.definition: The opposite of serendipity; making unhappy, unlucky discoveries by design; the faculty of making unhappy discoveries by chance.

examples: By checking his partner's phone, he experienced zemblanity when finding evidence of betrayal.
The auditor's investigation led to zemblanity as financial improprieties were systematically uncovered.
Some scientific research leads to zemblanity, revealing uncomfortable truths about our world.

definitions.definition: The eighth power of a number.

examples: Before modern mathematical notation, mathematicians used the term zenzizenzizenzic to represent x⁸.
The zenzizenzizenzic of 2 is 256, which can be calculated as 2 to the power of 8.
The archaic term zenzizenzizenzic appears in Robert Recorde's 1557 mathematical work 'The Whetstone of Witte.'

definitions.definition: A figure of speech in which a word applies to two others in different senses or to two others of which it semantically suits only one.

examples: The classic example of zeugma is 'She broke his car and his heart.'
The headline used zeugma cleverly: 'Politician Loses Election and Mind.'
Skilled comedians often employ zeugma to create unexpected humorous connections.

definitions.definition: A delusion in which one believes oneself to be an animal.

examples: Historical cases of zoanthropy include lycanthropy, where people believed they had transformed into wolves.
The psychiatrist specialized in treating rare delusions including zoanthropy.
In folklore, zoanthropy was often associated with magical curses or divine punishment.

definitions.definition: A situation, especially in chess, where a player is compelled to make a move that will worsen their position.
Any situation where one is forced to make a disadvantageous decision.

examples: The chess master maneuvered her opponent into zugzwang, forcing a fatal move.
The politician found himself in a political zugzwang: any response to the scandal would only damage his reputation further.
Contract negotiations reached a zugzwang when neither side could concede without significant loss.
